body: Metropolitan New York is being rapidly reshaped as blacks, Latinos, Asians and immigrants surge into the suburbs, while gentrification by whites is widening the income gap in neighborhoods in Manhattan and Brooklyn, according to new census figures released on Tuesday. Some of the largest population gains since 2000 were recorded in places that not
title: In New York, Black and Hispanic Strongholds Become More White

author: Christine Muhlke is food editor of The Times Magazine.
body: What confusing times these are. And I'm talking just about new cookbook offerings. Fall's usual glut of chef-y titles, primed for the giving, are notably absent. The food we're being offered is much simpler, much faster and removed from the realm of fantasy -- unless we're talking about ''Modernist Cuisine: The Art and Science of Cooking,'' the
title: Cooking

body: In a rampage loud enough to be heard by alarmed neighbors, an actor killed his mother with a three-foot sword early Tuesday in their apartment in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, the police said. Shortly after 1 a.m., the actor, Michael Brea, 31, asked his mother, Yannick Brea, 55, ''if she believed in God,'' said Greg Clare, who heard the commotion
title: Actor Killed Mother With a Sword, the Police Say

body: IT is not a sentiment commonly associated with New York City landlords, but for Malcolm Smart, some things are more important than money. ''I don't want someone I resent in my space,'' said Mr. Smart, the live-in owner of a Brooklyn brownstone with a one-bedroom rental apartment. ''If it means getting a few hundred dollars less in rent every month
title: Move Over, Fancy High-Rises

body: Topped with a dollop of thick whipped cream, the luxurious hot chocolate at Blue Marble Ice Cream in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, is an event in itself. As opening acts go, it's hard to beat -- a point clearly not lost on Abigail Browde and Michael Silverstone , the directors of ''This Time Tomorrow.'' The site-specific performance was inspired by,
title: DANCE REVIEW; Unusual Antics Unfold In a Church Basement

body: AS newlyweds, Brian and Bridget Applegate spent two years squeezed into a small one-bedroom on the Upper East Side. They were eager to buy, and it had to be a larger place. ''When I had to get medicine out if I was sick,'' Mrs. Applegate said, ''I had to remove three boxes of shoes to get into where it was stored. It wasn't like, 'Take something
title: THE HUNT; A Little Air, Indoors and Out

author: Rick Moody's latest novel is ''The Four Fingers of Death.''
body: THE street addresses of my life, and there have been a great number of them, have often felt less like home to me than the places I've written about. The New Canaan, Conn., of 1973, when I was writing about it in the early '90s. The Arizona of the near future, in a recent novel. I love landscapes of the imagination, less so the topographies of the
title: DOMESTIC LIVES; The Hazel Effect

body: ''So there's ULURP,'' begins the second song in a new musical about Brooklyn. ''ULURP is the Uniform Land Use Review Procedure/Which required community involvement and public review/Of all kinds of New York City land-use projects.'' If this seems like something you might read in the notes of a community board meeting, that's because it is. The song
title: In Brooklyn, Dramatizing Real Discord

body: With BoltBus, Megabus, and an array of Chinatown-to-Chinatown companies already operating, it might seem the market for discount New York-to-D.C. bus lines has reached capacity. But one upstart is betting there's room for a new angle. The Know It Express, which debuts Friday, bypasses Manhattan and downtown Washington altogether, instead offering
title: IN TRANSIT; Washington to Brooklyn By 'Hipster Highway' Bus

body: ''Are you familiar with the Frisco?'' I asked a bartender at Rye House, near Union Square, who in turn asked me to repeat myself, then had me spell the two syllables I had twice uttered. Still he was baffled. He took out his iPhone and sought to Google his way to illumination. But the recipe he found didn't match my rough memory and sense of what a
title: THE TIPSY DIARIES; Smitten With a Cocktail Called Frisco

body: AFTER graduating from the Juilliard School, Monica Ohuchi Bunch practiced and taught on her upright piano. Two years ago, she upgraded to a Steinway Grand, Model B, nearly seven feet long. It had to be lifted, via crane, into the apartment she shared with her husband, Kenji Bunch. They watched with their hearts in their throats as it entered their
title: THE HUNT; A Place to Make Music, Minus Noise

body: FROM the window of his waterfront office in the Dumbo section of Brooklyn, Sufjan Stevens can see traffic creeping along Manhattan's eastern edge, just across the river. He can see the party boats and barges float by, joined occasionally by groups of kayakers. And he can see the workers at the Con Edison power plant across from his building. It
title: Mr. Strummy-Strum Tries a Synth Sound

body: The way Joseph E. Joseph tells it, he was just doing his civic duty. On his way home from work one evening in 1992, he came across a group of volunteers in Brooklyn registering people to vote. Mr. Joseph, a legal permanent resident who had immigrated from St. Kitts eight years earlier, decided it was time to sign up. He cast a ballot in that year's
title: For Some Immigrants, Voting Is a Criminal Act

author: Frank Bruni is a staff writer for the magazine. His memoir, ''Born Round,'' was recently published in paperback.
body: ''IS HE COMING BACK?'' Clara Santos Perez was peering out the windows and across the street, where an imposing man in black stood, his face turned in her direction. Was he watching? Waiting? Planning to confront her anew? Perez wondered aloud about all of this, wrung her hands and paced. In her agitation and dread she more closely resembled a
title: SHARED PLATES; Keeping It Kosher

title: The Listings

body: VALERIE BERGER was nearly 60 but had never had her own place. She split her time between her mother's house and her boyfriend's apartment, both in Park Slope, Brooklyn. Then her boyfriend died of a surgery-related infection at age 70, a few years after her mother did. Unable to afford much else, Ms. Berger moved in April 2009 into the Y.W.C.A. in
title: At the Y, 'They Take Care of Each Other'

body: WHAT if your apartment roommate moved out abruptly with no forwarding address, leaving you to pay his half of that month's rent? Frantic mass e-mails and Facebook posts have yielded no replacements, and you are tired of dealing with spammers and strangers on Craigslist. With next month's rent looming, what do you do? One option is Roommates Wanted
title: POSTING; Mingle, Meet, and Maybe Move In

title: SPARE TIMES

body: The dispute began early Thursday over two dogs, a miniature pinscher named Rocco and a Shih Tzu, Bugsy, one tied too closely to the other outside a bar in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn. It was the type of minor skirmish common enough on the crowded sidewalks of New York. But as the owners of the dogs separated them, things quickly escalated. By the
title: Owner Killed After Dog Leashes Are Tangled

body: Market Designs on View An exhibition of the designs for a new marketplace for the food vendors in Red Hook, Brooklyn, is on display at the Queens Museum of Art in Flushing Meadow through Sunday from noon to 6 p.m. Wednesdays through Sundays. Admission is by donation. Taco Series Andrew Carmellini of Locanda Verde has turned his talent to Mexico and
title: Calendar

body: A former college basketball player pleaded guilty in Belgrade, Serbia, on Monday as part of a deal that would send him to prison for his role in a barroom brawl in Binghamton, N.Y., that left a classmate badly injured, the classmate's lawyers said. The former basketball player, Miladin Kovacevic, 23, was to have gone on trial two weeks ago. But the
title: Suspect Who Fled to Serbia Pleads Guilty in 2008 Beating

body: Comparing the buttoned-up experience of seeing a play to going to church is an old insult, but maybe it shouldn't be. Or at least that's what you might think while watching the dynamic modern-dress revival of T. S. Eliot's ''Murder in the Cathedral,'' which takes place in the pews, inside illuminated confessional booths and under the cross of a
title: THEATER REVIEW | 'MURDER IN THE CATHEDRAL'; Inside a Grand Church, His Days Are Numbered

body: A Serbian-born former college basketball player who fled the United States in 2008 is expected to plead guilty in Belgrade, Serbia, on Tuesday as part of a deal that would send him to prison for attacking a classmate in Binghamton, N.Y., officials who have been briefed on the case said Monday. The former basketball player, Miladin Kovacevic, was to
title: Guilty Plea Is Expected In Beating Of Classmate

body: FOR 12 years, Meaghan Jones lived in a series of Upper East Side high-rises. The main appeal: the buildings were convenient to her office. If anyone had asked her the names of her neighbors, she would have been stumped. ''I didn't talk to them,'' she said. ''I just came in and out.'' Typical New York apartment living, of course. But wait, there was
title: The Social Set

body: COLICCHIO & SONS 85 10th Avenue (15th Street), Chelsea; (212) 400-6699, colicchioandsons.com. A couture restaurant from Tom Colicchio in the space that used to be Craftsteak. A lot of the testosterone has been drained off, and a combination of flowers and a Grateful Dead-ish soundtrack do much to counter the boom-era feeling of the restaurant's
title: RECENTLY REVIEWED

body: SINCE their arrival in the city two years ago, Jennifer McCarron and Brandi Molitor have had more than their share of bad apartment luck. When the couple moved to the city from Albany, they took over a friend's lease on a one-bedroom rental in Sunnyside, Queens. Seven months in, roof construction led to a building fire, which destroyed most of
title: THE HUNT; A Lot of Laundry, and a Little Luck

body: Jeremy Sparig spent months fighting bedbugs. Now, to some people, he is like a mattress left on the street, something best avoided in these times. ''They don't want to hug you anymore; they don't want you coming over,'' said Mr. Sparig, of East Williamsburg, Brooklyn. ''You're like a leper.'' At the Brooklyn district attorney's office, which
title: What Spreads Faster Than Bedbugs? Fear and Social Stigma

author: E-mail: citycritic@nytimes.com
body: On the second story of East River Plaza, at 116th Street, wide sliding doors open onto an evenly lighted, color-coordinated, climate-controlled space and then slide shut again, cutting off the waft of 95-degree air plaguing the sidewalks of East Harlem. Suddenly all is calm: Street sounds are gone. Heat wave is gone. Sidewalk vendors are gone.
title: CITY CRITIC; It's Always Sunny In Targetland

body: ABC KITCHEN 35 East 18th Street, Flatiron district; (212) 475-5829, abckitchennyc.com. This winsome sprawl on the ground floor of ABC Carpet & Home was created by Jean-Georges Vongerichten. It's haute organic and Hamptons sustainable -- and airy, open and relaxed, the way the second homes of the wealthy often are. Ingredients, as a position paper
title: RECENTLY REVIEWED

body: To the residents of Prospect Heights in Brooklyn, he was simply known as Steve. He spent the last month stalking the neighborhood streets at night, breaking off the branches of young trees. Sometimes, he broke them off with his bare hands, other times he climbed into the trees and used his weight to tear off their limbs. Recently, he was seen
title: After Arrest in Attacks on Trees, Thinking More Than Just Oaks Need Help

author: E-mail: the hunt@nytimes.com
body: JUST over a year ago, Mark and Alejandra Ryan arrived in New York with little more than, as he put it, ''a healthy dose of naïveté.'' The couple chose New York for two reasons. It was the place where they had fallen in love. And it was a place where both could find work -- he in medicine and she in the media -- and ''neither would be giving
title: THE HUNT; Room for the Dog to Wag His Tail

body: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began. The ''time on the market'' is from the most recent listing to the sales agreement. body: I grew up thinking of the bloody mary as a joyless drink. It was a corrective after a night of head-cramping excess: the pitiable hair of the shameful dog. Or it was a quasi-sanctioned, quiet way for the booze-dependent to begin a sort of intravenous drip of alcohol early in the day. Either way, the bloody mary struck me as medicinal. Today it
title: TIPSY DIARIES; Bloody Mary, The Liquid Salad

body: Summer School A talk about garlic and other alliums, covering the science and folklore, will be given by Eric Block on July 2 at 11 a.m. in the Watson Education Building at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx, free with general admission. A class in making sushi, with cocktails to drink and sushi to eat, will be presented at 8 p.m. on July
title: Calendar

body: Citing problems with electrical equipment, Consolidated Edison announced on Monday that it had decreased voltage to parts of Brooklyn by 8 percent and asked customers there and in part of the Upper West Side of Manhattan not to use ''nonessential'' electrical appliances, including air-conditioners, until the problems were corrected. The utility
title: Con Ed Reports Power Problems in City

author: Dvora Meyers, a freelance writer and Hebrew teacher, lives in Clinton Hill, she writes about Judaism and gymnastics on her blog, at unorthodoxgymnastics.com; Ellen Levitt lives in Midwood and teaches social studies at a Brooklyn High school.
body: This week's Complaint Box features two views on one borough's identity crisis, from Dvora Meyers and Ellen Levitt. I'm From Brooklyn, She Said in Her Southern Drawl As a 27-year-old single woman living in Brooklyn, I enjoy the communal events that warm weather brings: summer concerts in Prospect Park, street fairs, outdoor dining with friends. But
title: CITY ROOM; Complaint Box | Borough Pride; I'm From Brooklyn, She Said in Her Southern Drawl

body: Over the last decade, a growing stream of the young, the stylish and the family-oriented have been drawn to Brooklyn by its parks, waterfront, cultural life and relatively affordable real estate and acres of graceful brownstones. But when it comes time for those newcomers to have their babies, they are tied as if by an umbilical cord to Manhattan.
title: A Manhattan Birth Certificate, But an Address in Brooklyn

author: Norman Oder, a Brooklyn journalist, has written the Atlantic Yards Report blog for more than four years.
body: The Russian billionaire Mikhail D. Prokhorov, the Nets' new majority owner and the N.B.A.'s first overseas owner, magnetized members of the news media during his recent whirlwind tour of New York. Prokhorov, a 6-foot-8 kick boxer, international playboy and shrewd businessman, did his best to make people forget the team's performance last year at
title: ESSAY; A Russian Billionaire, the Nets and Sweetheart Deals

body: THERE was a time, more than a century ago, when a stretch of mansions in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, was known as Millionaire's Row. Most of the biggest houses there are gone, and Crown Heights has had a busy history since that time. But if millionaires are scarcer today, the good news is that in much of the neighborhood the comfortable ambience they
title: LIVING IN | CROWN HEIGHTS, BROOKLYN; A Melting Pot, With the Heat Turned Off

body: The new ''Food Lovers' Guide to Brooklyn'' by Sherri Eisenberg (Globe Pequot Press, $14.95) is reasonably up-to-date for a borough where new food places open their doors by the minute. Its 328 pages are packed, district by district, with detailed listings, maps and descriptions. Some of the neighborhood groupings segue from one into another, like
title: FOOD STUFF; A Borough's Treats, Now in a Book

body: On the Screen Do not visit Scanwiches on an empty stomach. The blog, which Jon Chonko created in February 2009 for the dual purpose of ''education and delight,'' is like a restaurant menu on steroids. Viewed before lunch, a BLT Perfecto from Papa Lima in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, on toasted rye coated with basil mayonnaise, is enough to induce
title: CITY ROOM; NEW YORK ONLINE | SCANWICHES.COM

body: CENTENNIAL BEE-DAY PARTY In Kafka's ''Metamorphosis'' Gregor Samsa awakens to discover that he has become an enormous cockroach. While that may be among the most unwelcome transformations on record, the Brooklyn Botanic Garden will offer one on Saturday that's shorter, sweeter and sunnier: children changing themselves into bees. The process is part
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: IN a city said to be teeming with potential mates, where in New York do you look for a great catch? Are you supposed to hail them down on the street like a cab? That's one approach. In November 2005, Dimple Chaudhary was happily single, but wasn't against getting her feet wet. At a Brooklyn bar one night, she and her friend Abby Larson chatted with
title: VOWS; Dimple Chaudhary and Previn Warren

body: ANDREA SYRTASH realized one day why she should marry her good friend Michael Paoli. Because he was the one person she wouldn't mind being stuck in a foxhole with. And so, when the couple moved from their native Toronto to New York, taking over a tiny Greenwich Village one-bedroom from a friend, Mr. Paoli hugged his wife and said, ''We're in our
title: THE HUNT; An Apartment That's Just Their Type

body: THE service was slick, the room was handsome and the food reliably good at the Vanderbilt, a well-groomed gastropub that opened last fall in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn. But something was missing. It was not half as pleasurable as Kaz an Nou, a new French-Caribbean place two blocks away with half its size and sophistication. The Vanderbilt, 570
title: $25 AND UNDER; Neighbors, but So Far Apart

For more than 70 years, the bar has
title: Last Call Looms at Freddy's, In the Path of Atlantic Yards

body: Dinner Theater ''Bass for Picasso,'' an Off Broadway play by Kate Moira Ryan, is about a dinner party given by a food critic with a menu of dishes from the Alice B. Toklas cookbook. It will run through May 23 at the Kirk Theater, 410 West 42nd Street; (212) 279-4200, ticketcentral.com. New Jersey on a Plate Tastings from more than 50 restaurants in
title: Calendar

body: IN a city where the hot hangout changes by the minute, and people move to neighborhoods that are just starting to shed a commercial or industrial past, it is little surprise that New Yorkers sometimes wind up living in places that never before saw bed, sofa or stove. Some of the more intrepid renters and buyers over the years have set up house in
title: Born a Store

body: The street was crowded with students just out of school. Younger ones carried backpacks, while teenagers from two high schools popped in and out of stores. Suddenly, shots rang out from above. Residents of Crown Heights, Brooklyn, were still shaken on Thursday from that rooftop attack, which wounded four teenage boys and sent dozens of people
title: Crown Heights Unnerved as Police Hunt a Rooftop Gunman

body: Looking Ahead FORNINO PARK SLOPE Michael Ayoub, above, is spreading the brand of his locavore pizzeria from Williamsburg, Brooklyn, back to the place where he had his first venture, Cucina, a Park Slope pioneer that opened in 1990 and which he left in 2001. ''It's a little surreal,'' he said. ''Some of the stuff I put in is still here. It's like
title: Off the Menu

body: CLOSE your eyes and picture your dream apartment. Do you see light streaming through big open windows? Is there a large kitchen? Nice prewar detail? Now open your eyes and remember that you are in New York City -- an extraordinarily expensive place to live, recession or no recession. So, what would you sacrifice to get a great place? For many
title: The Everest Advantage

title: Spare Times

title: THE WEEK AHEAD | MARCH 14--MARCH 20

''Today's a
title: After Years of Controversy, Ceremonial Shovels Come Out

title: Inside The Times

body: There was buy an antenna. There was squeeze in front of the computer (really hard with 20 or 30 guests, and munchies). There was find a friend -- any friend -- in Manhattan. There was, alas, go to the in-laws. These were among the viable choices -- some not so bad and some pretty unfortunate -- that the three million Cablevision customers in the
title: Oscar Night Suspense, Then Poof! Cable's Back

body: IN the nine years since he came to New York with $500 in his pocket, Martin-Christopher Harper estimates that he has moved at least 40 times. When he lists the neighborhoods he has lived in -- in chronological order -- he sounds like a bartender reciting a long list of microbrews: ''Brooklyn, Chelsea Hotel for a moment, Bronx, Carroll Gardens,
title: Boxed In

body: A review last Wednesday about the Motorino pizzerias misidentified the location in Brooklyn of Franny's, one of the first upscale pizza restaurants in New York City. It is in Prospect Heights, not Park Slope.
title: Corrections

body: An employee of the mayor's office was declared brain-dead on Sunday morning after she and another woman were struck by a hit-and-run driver while crossing Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn, the authorities said. Around 4:30 a.m. on Sunday, a car traveling north on the avenue struck the women near the intersection of Prospect Place in Prospect Heights,
title: Hit and Run In Brooklyn Leaves One Brain-Dead

body: IT was Valentine's Day at the House of Yes, an old ice warehouse turned event space in Bushwick, Brooklyn: The three-story ''skybox'' was swathed in red satin and velvet, and red aerialists' silks hung from the circus truss that spanned the ceiling. Kae Burke, 23, who runs House of Yes with her high school pal Anya Sapozhnikova, twined her way up
title: Decorating the Night

body: THERE was a television crew in Motorino in Williamsburg a couple of weeks ago, Michelle Park from NY1 shooting a segment with the restaurant's chef, the elegant young Mathieu Palombino. He smiled shyly in chef's whites. There have been others. Fame stalks the restaurant, which has locations in Brooklyn and the East Village. Vice magazine came to
title: RESTAURANT REVIEW; A Pizza Place Grows Up

body: When Jennie Dundas and Alexis Miesen opened Blue Marble, a shop selling homemade ice cream on Atlantic Avenue in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, back in 2007, their checklist included organic ingredients, 16 percent butterfat and a child-friendly setting. Soft-serve ice cream was not in the picture there or at their second shop, in Prospect Heights. ''It
title: FOOD STUFF; Ice Cream Makers Embracing Their Soft Side

body: NEW YORK is one big sprawling city, full of people who are proud to call themselves New Yorkers. But sometimes it seems as if that were where the sameness ended. Just try to find a taxi on Staten Island or a gas station in Manhattan and you will quickly learn that there are big differences among the boroughs. Another way to experience that
title: Got 500,000 Clams? The City Is Your Oyster

body: The Hello Living condo project in Brooklyn was marketed as an urban utopia, a collection of low-rise apartments designed for young families without large inheritances or bonuses. More than three dozen of them closed on apartments, enticed by the modern designs set among the brick walk-ups of Prospect Heights and by amenities like a pool, a gym and
title: Families See A Utopia Turn Nightmarish In a Legal Fight

body: More than a half-dozen gentrified neighborhoods in Brooklyn would lose subsidized day care centers for low-income families under proposed city budget cuts, Bloomberg administration officials said Wednesday. A list of the 15 day care centers that are scheduled to close in July, 10 of them in Brooklyn, was released by the Administration for
title: City Seeks to Close 15 Day Care Centers, Most in Brooklyn, in Budget Cut

body: BY midafternoon on a recent Saturday, Bierkraft, the beer emporium and grocery on Fifth Avenue in Park Slope, Brooklyn, was half-filled with customers, many of them parents with babies or toddlers in tow. They were browsing the more than 1,000 varieties of bottled beer or surveying the listing of selections available on the 13 taps and 3 cask
title: The New Old Way To Tote Your Beer

body: Eating spiced lamb at a bustling Yemeni restaurant in Downtown Brooklyn, Mahib Alkrizy said that since Sept. 11, 2001, his wife, a religious Muslim who covers her hair, has come to expect being patted down and stared at when she travels by plane. Around the corner at Abu Yasser Travel Agency, employees waved a reporter away -- they were tired of
title: For Immigrants, New Travel Concerns
